article.para: White lists are most often used to give special privileges to a set of hosts within an organization. Let us suppose that we have the following environment:

listitem.para: A firewall with three interfaces -- one to the Internet, one to a local network and one to a DMZ.

The local network uses SNAT to the internet and is comprised of the Class B network 10.10.0.0/16 (Note: While this example uses an RFC 1918 local network, the technique described here in no way depends on that or on SNAT. It may be used with Proxy ARP, Subnet Routing, Static NAT, etc.).
The network operations staff have workstations with IP addresses in the Class C network 10.10.10.0/24.
We want the network operations staff to have full access to all other hosts.
We want the network operations staff to bypass the transparent HTTP proxy running on our firewall.

article.para: The basic approach will be that we will place the operations staff's class C in its own zone called ops. Here are the appropriate configuration files:
article.programlisting: #ZONE TYPE OPTIONS fw firewall net ipv4 ops ipv4 loc ipv4 dmz ipv4
article.para: The ops zone has been added to the standard 3-zone zones file -- since ops is a sub-zone of loc, we list it BEFORE loc.
article.programlisting: #ZONE INTERFACE BROACAST OPTIONS net eth0 <whatever> ... dmz eth1 <whatever> ... - eth2 10.10.255.255
article.para: Because eth2 interfaces to two zones (ops and loc), we don't specify a zone for it here.
article.programlisting: #ZONE HOST(S) OPTIONS ops eth2:10.10.10.0/24 loc eth2:0.0.0.0/0
article.para: Here we define the ops and loc zones. When Shorewall is stopped, only the hosts in the ops zone will be allowed to access the firewall and the DMZ. I use 0.0.0.0/0 to define the loc zone rather than 10.10.0.0/16 so that the limited broadcast address (255.255.255.255) falls into that zone. If I used 10.10.0.0/16 then I would have to have a separate entry for that special address.
article.programlisting: #SOURCE DEST POLICY LOG LEVEL ops all ACCEPT all ops CONTINUE loc net ACCEPT net all DROP info all all REJECT info
article.para: Two entries for ops (in bold) have been added to the standard 3-zone policy file.
article.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DEST PROTO DEST PORT(S) SOURCE PORTS(S) ORIGINAL DEST REDIRECT loc!ops 3128 tcp http
article.para: This is the rule that transparently redirects web traffic to the transparent proxy running on the firewall. The SOURCE column explicitly excludes the ops zone from the rule.
